studies.study_name: Social Categorization and Similarity in Intergroup Behaviour
hypotheses: Both similarity and social categorization should positively affect ingroup favouritism.
Social categorization per se (even when based on explicitly random criteria) is sufficient to produce ingroup favouritism.
Fairness is a determinant of subjects' decisions in intergroup reward allocation.
Similarity between individuals (without explicit categorization) might influence intergroup discrimination.

sub_studies.content: Participants completed two parts. Part 1 involved expressing preferences for pairs of abstract paintings (Klee vs. Kandinsky). In Part 2, they were assigned to conditions and asked to allot money to anonymous others using 24 reward matrices. The conditions varied by whether participants were explicitly categorized into 'groups' and whether the basis for categorization/grouping was similarity in art preference or random chance.

items.description: Measure of straightforward ingroup favouritism (FAV). Joint profit is impossible to maximize; fairness is in the center.
Measure of Ingroup Favouritism (FAV) vs. Maximum Joint Profit (MJP).
Measure of Ingroup Favouritism (FAV) vs. Fairness (F). Maximum Joint Profit (MJP) is constant.

participants.description: Schoolboys from an independent private school in Bristol.

statistical_results.claim: Both variables produced significant main effects on ingroup favouritism, with categorization being more important.

statistical_results.test_name: Wilcoxon Matched Pairs Test (Matrix 2 FAV vs MJP)
statistical_results.claim: Only categorization conditions showed significant ingroup favouritism over joint profit.

statistical_results.test_name: Wilcoxon Matched Pairs Test (Matrix 3 FAV vs Fairness)
statistical_results.claim: Categorization conditions showed significant ingroup favouritism even when in conflict with fairness.
Only the Categorization: Similarity condition's scores significantly differed from the point of no bias toward ingroup favouritism.

paper_title: Social categorization and similarity in intergroup behaviour
paper_abstract: The present study is one of a series exploring the role of social categorization in intergroup behaviour. It has been found in our previous studies that in ‘minimal’ situations, in which the subjects were categorized into groups on the basis of visual judgments they had made or of their esthetic preferences, they clearly discriminated against members of an outgroup although this gave them no personal advantage. However, in these previous studies division into groups was still made on the basis of certain criteria of ‘real‘ similarity between subjects who were assigned to the same category. Therefore, the present study established social categories on an explicitly random basis without any reference to any such real similarity. It was found that, as soon as the notion of ‘group’ was introduced into the situation, the subjects still discriminated against those assigned to another random category. This discrimination was considerably more marked than the one based on a division of subjects in terms of interindividual similarities in which the notion of ‘group’ was never explicitly introduced. In addition, it was found that fairness was also a determinant of the subjects’ decisions. The results are discussed from the point of view of their relevance to a social-cognitive theory of intergroup behaviour.
